official-title.#text:
Expressing the sense of the House of
		  Representatives that the Food and Drug Administration should encourage the use
		  of abuse-deterrent formulations of drugs.

cosponsor.#tail:
) submitted the following
			 resolution; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
should exercise its
			 acknowledged authority to—

text.#text: That it is the sense of the

refuse to approve
			 generic versions of non-abuse-deterrent opioid products that have been replaced
			 in the market with abuse-deterrent formulations; and

require generic
			 versions of abuse-deterrent opioid products to be formulated with comparable
			 abuse-deterrent features.

Whereas when abuse-deterrent formulations of a drug have
			 been developed, approved, and recognized as effective by the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Office of National Drug Control Policy

text.#text:
Whereas in response, several opioid drug manufacturers
			 have developed abuse-deterrent formulations;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
has the authority under
			 current law to require generic versions of products that have been formulated
			 or reformulated with abuse-deterrent features to have comparable features;
			 and

, which would similarly promote abuse-deterrent technologies in addictive
			 painkillers: Now, therefore, be it
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Stop Tampering with Prescription Pills (STOPP)
			 Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Stop Tampering with Prescription Pills (STOPP) Act

text.#text:
Whereas fourteen Members of Congress in a bipartisan
			 coalition have cosponsored the

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}title.#text: 113 HRES 161 IH: Expressing the sense of the House of Representatives that the Food and Drug Administration should encourage the use of abuse-deterrent formulations of drugs.
